entities.description: Ashley Taylor is an Indigenous Australian professional rugby league footballer who plays as a five-eighth and halfback for the Gold Coast Titans in the NRL.

heading: Births
txt: Katie Ledecky, American swimmer

entities.title: Katie Ledecky
entities.description: Kathleen Genevieve Ledecky is an American competitive swimmer. She has won five Olympic gold medals and 15 world championship gold medals, the most in history for a female swimmer. She is the world record holder in the women's 400-, 800-, and 1500-meter freestyle. She also holds the fastest-ever times in the women's 500-, 1000-, and 1650-yard freestyle events.

heading: Deaths
txt: Titus Labienus, Roman general (b. 100 BC)

entities.title: Titus Labienus
entities.description: Titus Labienus was a professional Roman soldier in the late Roman Republic. He served as tribune of the Plebs in 63 BC. Although remembered as one of Julius Caesar's lieutenants in Gaul, mentioned frequently in the accounts of his military campaigns, Labienus chose to oppose him during the Civil War and was killed at Munda. He was the father of Quintus Labienus.

heading: Deaths
txt: Publius Attius Varus, Roman governor of Africa

heading: Deaths
txt: Marcus Aurelius, Roman emperor (b. 121)

entities.title: Marcus Aurelius
entities.description: Caesar Marcus Aurelius Antoninus, born Severus Annius Verus, better known as Marcus Aurelius ə-REE-lee-əs; Latin: [ˈmaːrkʊs̠ au̯ˈreːlijʊs̠ an̪t̪oːˈniːnʊs̠]; 26 April 121 – 17 March 180), was Roman emperor from 161 to 180 and a Stoic philosopher. He was the last of the rulers known as the Five Good Emperors, and the last emperor of the Pax Romana, an age of relative peace and stability for the Roma

heading: Deaths
txt: Amr ibn Hishām, Arab polytheist

entities.title: Amr ibn Hishām
entities.description: ʿAmr ibn Hishām al-Makhzumi, also called Abu al-Hakam or Abū Jahl, was one of the Meccan polytheist pagan leaders from Quraysh known for his opposition towards the Islamic prophet Muhammad and the early Muslims in Mecca.

heading: Deaths
txt: Gertrude of Nivelles, Frankish abbess

entities.title: Gertrude of Nivelles
entities.description: Gertrude of Nivelles, O.S.B. was a seventh-century abbess who, with her mother Itta, founded the Abbey of Nivelles located in present-day Belgium.

heading: Deaths
txt: Haito, bishop of Basel

entities.title: Haito
entities.description: Haito was a Christian monk and Bishop of Basel.

heading: Deaths
txt: Li Yu, Prince of De, prince and emperor of the Tang Dynasty

entities.title: Li Yu, Prince of De
entities.description: Li Yu (李裕), né Li You (李祐), briefly Li Zhen (李縝), formally the Prince of De (德王), was an imperial prince of the Chinese dynasty Tang Dynasty. He was the oldest son of the penultimate emperor Emperor Zhaozong and Empress He and was Crown Prince from 897 to 900. In 900, Emperor Zhaozong was briefly forced by the eunuch Liu Jishu to abdicate in Li Yu's favor; after Emperor Zhaozong was restored, Li Y

heading: Deaths
txt: Kazan, emperor of Japan (b. 968)

entities.title: Emperor Kazan
entities.description: Emperor Kazan  was the 65th emperor of Japan, according to the traditional order of succession.

heading: Deaths
txt: Harold Harefoot, king of England

entities.title: Harold Harefoot
entities.description: Harold I, also known as Harold Harefoot, was King of England from 1035 to 1040. Harold's nickname "Harefoot" is first recorded as "Harefoh" or "Harefah" in the twelfth century in the history of Ely Abbey, and according to some late medieval chroniclers it meant that he was "fleet of foot".

heading: Deaths
txt: Lulach, king of Scotland

entities.title: Lulach
entities.description: Lulach mac Gille Coemgáin was King of Scots between 15 August 1057 and 17 March 1058.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jocelin of Glasgow, Scottish monk and bishop (b. 1130)

entities.title: Jocelin of Glasgow
entities.description: Jocelin was a twelfth-century Cistercian monk and cleric who became the fourth Abbot of Melrose before becoming Bishop of Glasgow, Scotland. He was probably born in the 1130s, and in his teenage years became a monk of Melrose Abbey. He rose in the service of Abbot Waltheof, and by the time of the short abbacy of Waltheof's successor Abbot William, Jocelin had become prior. Then in 1170 Jocelin him

heading: Deaths
txt: Pierre de Montreuil, French architect

entities.title: Pierre de Montreuil
entities.description: Pierre de Montreuil was a French architect. The name formerly given to him by architectural historians, Peter of Montereau, is a misnomer. It was based on his tombstone inscription Musterolo natus, a place name that was mistakenly identified as Montereau rather than Montreuil.

heading: Deaths
txt: Philip of Montfort, French knight and nobleman

entities.title: Philip of Montfort, Lord of Tyre
entities.description: Philip Ι of Montfort, was Lord of La Ferté-Alais and Castres-en-Albigeois 1228–1270, Lord of Tyre 1246–1270, and Lord of Toron aft. 1240–1270. He was the son of Guy of Montfort and Helvis of Ibelin.

heading: Deaths
txt: Go-Saga, emperor of Japan (b. 1220)

entities.title: Emperor Go-Saga
entities.description: Emperor Go-Saga  was the 88th emperor of Japan, according to the traditional order of succession. This reign spanned the years 1242 through 1246.

heading: Deaths
txt: An-Nasir Hasan, Mamluk sultan of Egypt

entities.title: An-Nasir Hasan
entities.description: An-Nasir Badr ad-Din Hasan ibn Muhammad ibn Qalawun, better known as an-Nasir Hasan, was the Mamluk sultan of Egypt, and the seventh son of an-Nasir Muhammad to hold office, reigning twice in 1347–1351 and 1354–1361. During his first reign, which he began at age 12, senior Mamluk emirs formerly belonging to an-Nasir Muhammad, dominated his administration, while an-Nasir Hasan played a ceremonial r

heading: Deaths
txt: Louis of Enghien, French nobleman

entities.title: Louis, Count of Enghien
entities.description: Louis of Enghien titular Duke of Athens, Count of Brienne and Lord of Enghien in 1381–1394, Count of Conversano in 1356–1394. His coat-of-arms was "Enghien, a label gules bezantee".

heading: Deaths
txt: Ibn Khaldun, Tunisian sociologist, historian, and scholar (b. 1332)

entities.title: Ibn Khaldun
entities.description: Ibn Khaldun was an Arab sociologist, philosopher and historian who has been described as the founder of the modern disciplines of historiography, sociology, economics, and demography. Niccolò Machiavelli of the Renaissance and the 19th-century European scholars widely acknowledged the significance of his works and considered Ibn Khaldun to be one of the greatest philosophers of the Middle Ages.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ashikaga Yoshikazu, Japanese shōgun (b. 1407)

entities.title: Ashikaga Yoshikazu
entities.description: Ashikaga Yoshikazu  was the 5th shōgun of the Ashikaga shogunate who reigned from 1423 to 1425 during the Muromachi period of Japan. Yoshikazu was the son of the fourth shōgun Ashikaga Yoshimochi.

heading: Deaths
txt: Giuliano de' Medici, Italian nobleman (b. 1479)

entities.title: Giuliano de' Medici, Duke of Nemours
entities.description: Giuliano di Lorenzo de' Medici KG was an Italian nobleman, the third son of Lorenzo the Magnificent, and a ruler of Florence.

heading: Deaths
txt: Rana Sanga, Indian ruler (b. 1482)

entities.title: Rana Sanga
entities.description: Rana Sangram Singh Sisodia, popularly known as Rana Sanga, was an Indian Hindu ruler of Mewar who reunited several Rajput clans to form a powerful Rajput confederation in Rajputana during the 16th century. He succeeded his father, Rana Raimal, to the Mewar throne in 1508. Sanga contemporarily fought against the Afghan Lodhi dynasty and Turkic Mughals during his lifetime. At its peak, his dominion

heading: Deaths
txt: Alexander Ales, Scottish theologian and academic (b. 1500)

entities.title: Alexander Ales
entities.description: Alexander Ales or Alexander Alesius was a Scottish theologian who immigrated to Germany and became a Lutheran supporter of the Augsburg Confession.

heading: Deaths
txt: Sophia of Sweden, duchess of Saxe-Lauenburg (b. 1547)

entities.title: Princess Sophia of Sweden
entities.description: Princess Sophia of Sweden, also Sofia Gustavsdotter Vasa, was a Swedish princess, daughter of King Gustav Vasa of Sweden and Margareta Leijonhufvud. She was formally Duchess consort of Saxe-Lauenburg by her marriage to Duke Magnus II of Saxe-Lauenburg.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Sarkander, Polish-Moravian priest and saint (b. 1576)

entities.title: John Sarkander
entities.description: Jan Sarkander was a Polish-Czech Roman Catholic priest. Sarkander was married for a short period of time before he became widowed and pursued a path to the priesthood where he became active in the defense of the faith during a period of anti-Catholic sentiment and conflict. He himself was arrested on false accusations as a means of silencing him and he refused to give in to his tormenters who tort

heading: Deaths
txt: Philip Massinger, English playwright (b. 1583)

entities.title: Philip Massinger
entities.description: Philip Massinger was an English dramatist. His finely plotted plays, including A New Way to Pay Old Debts, The City Madam and The Roman Actor, are noted for their satire and realism, and their political and social themes.

heading: Deaths
txt: Gabriel Lalemant, French missionary and saint (b. 1610)

entities.title: Gabriel Lalemant
entities.description: Gabriel Lalemant was a Jesuit missionary in New France beginning in 1646. Caught up in warfare between the Huron and nations of the Iroquois Confederacy, he was killed in St. Ignace by Mohawk warriors and is one of the eight Canadian Martyrs.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jerome Weston, 2nd Earl of Portland, English diplomat (b. 1605)

entities.title: Jerome Weston, 2nd Earl of Portland
entities.description: Jerome Weston, 2nd Earl of Portland was an English diplomat and landowner who held the presidency of Munster, Kingdom of Ireland.

heading: Deaths
txt: François de La Rochefoucauld, French author (b. 1613)

entities.title: François de La Rochefoucauld (writer)
entities.description: François VI, Duc de La Rochefoucauld, Prince de Marcillac was a noted French moralist and author of maxims and memoirs. He is part of the literary movement of classicism and best known for his maxims. Although he only officially published his Memoirs and his Maxims, his literary production is dense.

heading: Deaths
txt: Menno van Coehoorn, Dutch soldier and engineer (b. 1641)

entities.title: Menno van Coehoorn
entities.description: Menno, Baron van Coehoorn was a Dutch soldier and engineer, regarded as one of the most significant figures in Dutch military history. In an era when siege warfare dominated military campaigns, he and his French counterpart Vauban were the acknowledged experts in designing, taking and defending fortifications.

heading: Deaths
txt: Gilbert Burnet, Scottish bishop and historian (b. 1643)

entities.title: Gilbert Burnet
entities.description: Gilbert Burnet was a Scottish philosopher and historian, and Bishop of Salisbury. He was fluent in Dutch, French, Latin, Greek, and Hebrew. Burnet was highly respected as a cleric, a preacher, an academic, a writer and a historian. He was always closely associated with the Whig party, and was one of the few close friends in whom King William III confided.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean-Baptiste Rousseau, French poet and playwright (b. 1671)

entities.title: Jean-Baptiste Rousseau
entities.description: Jean-Baptiste Rousseau was a French playwright and poet, particularly noted for his cynical epigrams.

heading: Deaths
txt: George Parker, 2nd Earl of Macclesfield, English astronomer and politician (b. 1695)

entities.title: George Parker, 2nd Earl of Macclesfield
entities.description: George Parker, 2nd Earl of Macclesfield, PRS was an English peer and astronomer.

heading: Deaths
txt: Daniel Bernoulli, Dutch-Swiss mathematician and physicist (b. 1700)

entities.title: Daniel Bernoulli
entities.description: Daniel Bernoulli FRS was a Swiss mathematician and physicist and was one of the many prominent mathematicians in the Bernoulli family from Basel. He is particularly remembered for his applications of mathematics to mechanics, especially fluid mechanics, and for his pioneering work in probability and statistics. His name is commemorated in the Bernoulli's principle, a particular example of the cons

heading: Deaths
txt: James Edward Smith, English botanist and entomologist (b. 1759)

entities.title: James Edward Smith
entities.description: Sir James Edward Smith was an English botanist and founder of the Linnean Society.

heading: Deaths
txt: Sophia Albertina, princess-abbess of Quedlinburg (b. 1753)

entities.title: Sophia Albertina, Abbess of Quedlinburg
entities.description: Princess Sophia Albertina of Sweden was the last Princess-Abbess of Quedlinburg Abbey, and as such reigned as vassal monarch of the Holy Roman Empire.

heading: Deaths
txt: Laurent de Gouvion Saint-Cyr, French general and politician (b. 1764)

entities.title: Laurent de Gouvion Saint-Cyr
entities.description: Laurent de Gouvion Saint-Cyr, 1st Marquis of Gouvion-Saint-Cyr was a French commander in the French Revolutionary and Napoleonic Wars who rose to Marshal of the Empire and Marquis.

heading: Deaths
txt: Friedrich Bessel, German astronomer, mathematician, and physicist (b. 1784)

entities.title: Friedrich Bessel
entities.description: Friedrich Wilhelm Bessel was a German astronomer, mathematician, physicist and geodesist. He was the first astronomer who determined reliable values for the distance from the sun to another star by the method of parallax. A special type of mathematical functions were named Bessel functions after Bessel's death, though they had originally been discovered by Daniel Bernoulli and then generalised by

heading: Deaths
txt: William II, Dutch sovereign prince and king (b. 1792)

entities.title: William II of the Netherlands
entities.description: William II was King of the Netherlands, Grand Duke of Luxembourg, and Duke of Limburg.

heading: Deaths
txt: Christian Doppler, Austrian physicist and mathematician (b. 1803)

entities.title: Christian Doppler
entities.description: Christian Andreas Doppler was an Austrian mathematician and physicist. He is celebrated for his principle – known as the Doppler effect – that the observed frequency of a wave depends on the relative speed of the source and the observer. He used this concept to explain the color of binary stars.

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert Chambers, Scottish geologist and publisher, co-founded Chambers Harrap (b. 1802)

entities.title: Robert Chambers (publisher born 1802)
entities.description: Robert Chambers was a Scottish publisher, geologist, evolutionary thinker, author and journal editor who, like his elder brother and business partner William Chambers, was highly influential in mid-19th-century scientific and political circles.

entities.title: Chambers Harrap
entities.description: Chambers is a reference publisher formerly based in Edinburgh, Scotland, which held the property rights of the venerable W. R. Chambers Publishers.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ferdinand Laub, Czech violinist and composer (b. 1832)

entities.title: Ferdinand Laub
entities.description: Ferdinand Laub was a Czech violinist and composer.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jules Ferry, French lawyer and politician, 44th Prime Minister of France (b. 1832)

entities.title: Jules Ferry
entities.description: Jules François Camille Ferry was a French statesman and republican. He was one of the leaders of the Moderate Republicans and served as Prime Minister of France from 1880 to 1881 and 1883 to 1885. He was a promoter of laicism and colonial expansion.

entities.title: Prime Minister of France
entities.description: The prime minister of the French Republic, sometimes shortened to premier, is the head of government of France. During the Third and Fourth Republics, the head of government was formally called president of the Council of Ministers, generally shortened to president of the Council. However, the post was usually called "prime minister" or "premier" in non-French sources. The prime minister is the ho

heading: Deaths
txt: Franz Brentano, German philosopher and psychologist (b. 1838)

entities.title: Franz Brentano
entities.description: Franz Clemens Honoratus Hermann Josef Brentano was an influential German philosopher, psychologist, and Catholic priest whose work strongly influenced not only students Edmund Husserl, Sigmund Freud, Tomáš Masaryk, Rudolf Steiner, Alexius Meinong, Carl Stumpf, Anton Marty, Kazimierz Twardowski, and Christian von Ehrenfels, but many others whose work would follow and make use of his original ideas

heading: Deaths
txt: Aleksei Brusilov, Georgian-Russian general (b. 1853)

entities.title: Aleksei Brusilov
entities.description: Aleksey Alekseyevich Brusilov was a Russian general most noted for the development of new offensive tactics used in the 1916 Brusilov Offensive, which was his greatest achievement. The innovative and relatively successful tactics used were later copied by the Germans. Born into the aristocracy to a father who was also a general, Brusilov trained as a cavalry officer, but by 1914 he realized that c

heading: Deaths
txt: Austen Chamberlain, English politician, Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1863)

entities.title: Austen Chamberlain
entities.description: Sir Joseph Austen Chamberlain was a British statesman, son of Joseph Chamberlain and older half-brother of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain. He served as Chancellor of the Exchequer (twice) and was briefly Conservative Party leader before serving as Foreign Secretary.

entities.title: Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs
entities.description: The secretary of state for foreign, Commonwealth and development affairs, commonly known as the foreign secretary, is a senior minister of the Crown within the Government of the United Kingdom, and head of the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office. As one of the four Great Offices of State, the foreign secretary is a senior member of the British Cabinet.

entities.title: Nobel Peace Prize
entities.description: The Nobel Peace Prize is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Swedish industrialist, inventor, and armaments manufacturer Alfred Nobel, along with the prizes in Chemistry, Physics, Physiology or Medicine, and Literature. Since March 1901, it has been awarded annually to those who have "done the most or the best work for fraternity between nations, for the abolition or reduction

heading: Deaths
txt: Philomène Belliveau, Canadian artist (b. 1854)

entities.title: Philomène Belliveau
entities.description: Philomène Belliveau was a Canadian artist of Acadian descent.

heading: Deaths
txt: Dai Li, Chinese general (b. 1897)

entities.title: Dai Li
entities.description: Lieutenant General Dai Li (Tai Li; Chinese: 戴笠; pinyin: Dài Lì; Wade–Giles: Tai4 Li4; May 28, 1897 – March 17, 1946) was a Chinese spymaster. His courtesy name is Yunong (雨農). Born Dai Chunfeng (Tai Chun-feng; 戴春風) in Bao'an, Jiangshan of Qing Dynasty China's Zhejiang province, he studied at the Whampoa Military Academy, where Chiang Kai-shek served as Chief Commandant, and later became head of Ch

heading: Deaths
txt: Aleksandra Ekster, Russian-French painter and set designer (b. 1882)

entities.title: Aleksandra Ekster
entities.description: Aleksandra Aleksandrovna Ekster, also known as Alexandra Exter, was a Russian and French painter and designer.

heading: Deaths
txt: Fred Allen, American actor, comedian, screenwriter, and author (b. 1894)

entities.title: Fred Allen
entities.description: John Florence Sullivan, known professionally as Fred Allen, was an American comedian. His absurdist, topically pointed radio program The Fred Allen Show (1932–1949) made him one of the most popular and forward-looking humorists in the Golden Age of American radio.

heading: Deaths
txt: Irène Joliot-Curie, French physicist and chemist, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1897)

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Chemistry
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Chemistry is awarded annually by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences to scientists in the various fields of chemistry. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895, awarded for outstanding contributions in chemistry, physics, literature, peace, and physiology or medicine. heading: Deaths
txt: Ramon Magsaysay, Filipino captain and politician, 7th President of the Philippines (b. 1907)

entities.title: Ramon Magsaysay
entities.description: Ramon del Fierro Magsaysay, Sr. was a Filipino statesman who served as the seventh president of the Philippines, from December 30, 1953 until his death in an aircraft disaster. An automobile mechanic by profession, Magsaysay was appointed military governor of Zambales after his outstanding service as a guerrilla leader during the Pacific War. He then served two terms as Liberal Party congressman f

entities.title: President of the Philippines
entities.description: The president of the Philippines is the head of state and the head of government of the Philippines. The president leads the executive branch of the Philippine government and is the commander-in-chief of the Armed Forces of the Philippines. The president is directly elected by the people, and is one of only two nationally elected executive officials, the other being the vice president of the Phili

heading: Deaths
txt: John Pius Boland, Irish tennis player and politician (b. 1870)

entities.title: John Pius Boland
entities.description: John Mary Pius Boland was an Irish Nationalist politician, and Member of Parliament (MP) in the House of Commons of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland and as member of the Irish Parliamentary Party for South Kerry 1900–1918. He was also noteworthy as a gold medallist tennis player at the first modern Olympics.

He served as the head football coach at the International YMCA Training School (1890–1891), the University of Chicago (1892–1932), and the College of the Pacific (1933–1946), compiling a career college football record of 314–199–35 (.605). txt: Louis Kahn, American architect and academic, designed Jatiyo Sangsad Bhaban (b. 1901)

entities.title: Louis Kahn
entities.description: Louis Isadore Kahn was an American architect, based in Philadelphia. After working in various capacities for several firms in Philadelphia, he founded his own atelier in 1935. While continuing his private practice, he served as a design critic and professor of architecture at Yale School of Architecture from 1947 to 1957. From 1957 until his death, he was a professor of architecture at the School

entities.title: Jatiyo Sangsad Bhaban
entities.description: Jatiya Sangsad Bhaban or National Parliament House, is the house of the Parliament of Bangladesh, located at Sher-e-Bangla Nagar in the Bangladeshi capital of Dhaka. Designed while the country was still part of Pakistan by architect Louis Kahn, the complex is one of the largest legislative complexes in the world, comprising 200 acres.

Visconti was one of the fathers of Italian neorealism in film, but later moved towards luxurious-looking films obsessed with beauty, death and European history – especially the decay of aristocracy. entities.description: Paul Dee Dean, nicknamed "Daffy", was an American Major League Baseball right-handed pitcher. Born in Lucas, Arkansas, he pitched for the St. Louis Cardinals, the New York Giants, and the St. Louis Browns (1943).

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine is awarded yearly by the Nobel Assembly at the Karolinska Institutet for outstanding discoveries in physiology or medicine.

heading: Deaths

entities.description: Capucine was a French fashion model and actress known for her comedic roles in The Pink Panther (1963) and What's New Pussycat? (1965). She appeared in 36 films and 17 television productions between 1948 and 1990.

txt: Charlotte Auerbach, German-Jewish Scottish folklorist, geneticist, and zoologist (b. 1899)

entities.title: Charlotte Auerbach
entities.description: Charlotte "Lotte" Auerbach FRS FRSE was a German geneticist who contributed to founding the science of mutagenesis. She became well known after 1942 when she discovered with A. J. Clark and J. M. Robson that mustard gas could cause mutations in fruit flies. She wrote 91 scientific papers, and was a Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh and of the Royal Society of London.

entities.title: Prime Minister of Vietnam
entities.description: The prime minister of Vietnam, officially styled Prime Minister of the Government of the Socialist Republic, is the head of government of Vietnam who presides over the meetings of the Central Government. The prime minister directs the work of government members, and may propose deputy prime ministers to the National Assembly.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Magufuli, the fifth President of Tanzania (b. 1959)

entities.title: John Magufuli
entities.description: John Pombe Joseph Magufuli was the fifth president of Tanzania, serving from 2015 until his death in 2021. He served as Minister of Works, Transport and Communications from 2000 to 2005 and 2010 to 2015 and was chairman of the Southern African Development Community from 2019 to 2020.

entities.title: President of Tanzania
entities.description: The president of the United Republic of Tanzania is the head of state and head of government of Tanzania. The president leads the executive branch of the Government of Tanzania and is the commander-in-chief of the armed forces. The president serves a term of five years. Since 1992, they are limited to two terms, whether successive or separated.
